channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Defies Russia With Attacks on Crimea, a ‘Holy Land’ to Putin
item.description: A senior Ukrainian official said that an elite military unit was responsible for the attack on an ammunition storage site, the latest to directly target the peninsula that holds special meaning for Russian President Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Iraq Power Struggle Intensifies as Protesters Block Parliament
item.description: Followers of the Shiite Muslim cleric Muqtada al-Sadr set up a tent city to blockade Parliament, paralyzing any progress toward forming a new government.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Emily Rhyne

item.title: In Ukraine, Ravers Clean Up Rubble (to a Beat)
item.description: More than 100,000 buildings in Ukraine have been destroyed in the war. Volunteers are clearing away the rubble — and partying while they do it.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: Music played as the volunteers worked on.

item.title: A Royal Family Feuds Over Who Should be King of the Zulus
item.description: Who should rightfully inherit the throne of the legendary King Shaka Zulu? Some royals have criticized the leading contender as a reckless playboy unfit to lead a storied African monarchy.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Misuzulu Sinqobile Zulu, during an interview with The New York Times, in Durban, South Africa, in May.

item.title: How India’s Capital Is Fixing Its Schools
item.description: The Aam Aadmi Party, which rose to power in New Delhi, is overhauling an education system that serves as a lifeline for millions of families looking to break the cycle of poverty.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: A classroom at Sarvodaya Vidyalaya in New Delhi. The transformation of Delhi’s education system has made public schools more successful and desirable.

item.title: After a Bitter Contest, Kenyan Opposition Leader Rejects Election Result
item.description: Raila Odinga said the result announced on Monday, declaring his rival William Ruto as president-elect, should be annulled. The dispute looks set to go to court.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Abdi Latif Dahir and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Raila Odinga speaking with the crowd before addressing the nation at his campaign headquarters in Nairobi on Tuesday.

item.title: After 16 Months, Some Glimmers of Optimism About Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Iran’s response to the “final text,” sent to the European Union just before midnight Monday, does not raise major new objections, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Iran's chief nuclear negotiator, Ali Bagheri Kani, leaves the Palais Coburg, the venue where closed-door nuclear talks take place in Vienna, this month.

item.title: 10 Years After Disappearing in Syria, Freedom Is Elusive for U.S. Journalist
item.description: There are signs that efforts to free Austin Tice, who disappeared in Syria in 2012 and who the U.S. believes is being held by the Syrian government, are reviving. But his family says the U.S. needs to do more.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Debra Tice, center, the mother of Austin Tice, with employees of The Washington Post during the unveiling of a “#BringAustinHome” banner outside the newspaper’s headquarters in Washington last week.

item.title: Coptic Leader Criticizes Egypt’s Building Restrictions on Churches After Deadly Fire
item.description: The patriarch of Egypt’s 10 million Coptic Orthodox Christians said his community has been squeezed by decades of government regulations on the number and size of churches. In Sunday’s blaze, 41 people died.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Mourners carrying coffins of victims killed in the Cairo Coptic Church fire at a funeral. Eighteen children and the bishop conducting the Divine Liturgy were among the 41 people who died at the church on Sunday.

item.title: The Secret Powers of an Australian Prime Minister, Now Revealed
item.description: Scott Morrison was busy during the pandemic. In addition to being prime minister, he covertly put himself in charge of five ministries. Critics say he damaged democracy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Scott Morrison, center, during a cabinet meeting in Canberra, Australia, in 2020.

item.title: Leadership Vacuum Heightens Worries as Crises Loom in U.K.
item.description: As energy prices and inflation soar under a caretaker prime minister, critics say transition at the top is leaving Britons in limbo at a tumultuous moment.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, third from left, is working out his last few weeks in Downing Street before a successor is announced on Sept. 5.

item.title: Russia Fights Efforts to Declare It an Exporter of ‘Blood Diamonds’
item.description: As a major diamond producer, Russia earns billions of dollars that other nations say help finance war. The clash exposes the many loopholes in regulation of conflict diamonds.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The world is looking for ways to further restrict Russian earnings from exports beyond oil sales. Diamonds being evaluated at Alrosa, Russia’s diamond-mining giant, in 2018.

item.title: Marshall Islands, Once Nearly Covid-Free, Confronts an Outbreak
item.description: It was one of the last places on the planet to see its first Covid-19 cases. Now the virus is spreading rapidly.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Coral atolls that are part of the Marshall Islands. The country has, until recently, largely been spared by the coronavirus.

item.title: A Walrus Named Freya Showed Up in Norway. Did She Have to Die?
item.description: Three days after issuing a warning, the authorities put down the 1,300-pound marine mammal. Critics said that the decision was unnecessary.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Tor Erik Schroder/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Freya the walrus in Oslo last month. The Norwegian authorities said that the animal posed too big a threat to humans who failed to listen to repeated warnings to stay away from her.

item.title: The Party of Trump
item.description: A look at the latest results from last night’s primaries, and their larger meaning for the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liz Cheney’s concession speech in Jackson, Wyo.

item.title: North Korea Launches Two Missiles in First Test Since June
item.description: The test came as South Korea was gearing up for joint military drills with the United States and offered economic assistance to the North.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: South Korea’s president, Yoon Suk-yeol, at a news conference on Wednesday. Urging North Korea to take steps to end its nuclear program, he pledged diplomatic and economic support.

item.title: Mexico Sees Its Energy Future in Fossil Fuels, Not Renewables
item.description: The president’s push to bring the energy sector under state control has put up roadblocks to renewable energy and left Mexico’s climate goals behind.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico last month at the Olmeca Dos Bocas refinery in Paraiso, Mexico.

item.title: At Last, Online Travel Planning Is Becoming (a Little) Easier
item.description: Airbnb, Google Travel and a few other platforms have tweaked their search engines, and that means less slogging through pages and pages of results on everything from home rental options to flight routes.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Read Your Way Through Reykjavík
item.description: With a reputation for having more authors per capita than any other country, Iceland is a destination for readers. Olaf Olafsson, whose most recent book is “Touch,” leads a literary stroll through its capital.
item.dc:creator: Olaf Olafsson

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Attacks in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Smoke rising from explosions at a Russian ammunition depot in the Dzhankoi district of Crimea on Tuesday.

item.title: Behind Enemy Lines, Ukrainians Tell Russians ‘You Are Never Safe’
item.description: Clandestine resistance cells are spotting targets, sabotaging rail lines and killing those deemed collaborators as they seek to unnerve Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Ukrainian underground resistance, code-named Svarog, was made available for an interview by the Ukrainian military.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Again in Crimea, Posing a New Challenge for Putin
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has made Russia’s seizure of the peninsula a centerpiece of his 22-year rule, but a series of clandestine attacks by Ukrainian forces recently have tested security there.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Smoke rising from explosions at a Russian ammunition depot in the Dzhankoi district of Crimea on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: New Blasts Shake Crimea
item.description: Plus a political scandal grows in Australia and New Delhi offers a model for India’s schools.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Crimea, struck by an elite Ukrainian unit yesterday, has been a key base of operations for Russia throughout the war.

item.title: The first U.N. ship transporting Ukrainian grain to Africa has set sail.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.N. chartered cargo ship Brave Commander set sail from Ukraine on Tuesday. The vessel, loaded with thousands of metric tons of wheat, is headed to Ethiopia in the Horn of Africa.

item.title: New Water Cuts Announced as Colorado River Hits Dangerous Low
item.description: For now, the water-use reductions affect only Arizona and Nevada, together with Mexico. But talks to avoid wider cuts have so far achieved “exactly nothing.”
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The water levels of Lake Powell, behind the Glen Canyon Dam near the Arizona-Utah border, could drop so low next year that the dam could no longer generate hydropower.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Train for the Frontlines on British Soil
item.description: About 2,000 recruits have completed the program and returned to Ukraine. The program aims to train tens of thousands more.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A Ukrainian recruit in a mock battle at a training village in southeast England on Monday.

item.title: Why Crimea Plays a Critical Role in Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: The peninsula, which Moscow seized from Ukraine in 2014, has been a critical staging ground for the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Denis Sinyakov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Primorsky beach in Yalta, Crimea, in 2017.

item.title: Chinese Military Ship Docks in Sri Lanka Despite India’s Concerns
item.description: The arrival of the surveillance vessel has aggravated tensions as the two Asian giants compete for influence in the region.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Yuan Wang 5, a Chinese surveillance ship, arriving at the Hambantota port in southern Sri Lanka on Tuesday.

item.title: A Functional Congress? Yes.
item.description: Congress is known for being dysfunctional. Why hasn’t it been over the past two years?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sun rising over the U.S. Capitol in Washington on Sunday.

item.title: Killing of Ranger Protecting Rhinos Raises Fears for Conservation Efforts
item.description: The fatal shooting of the head ranger at the Timbavati reserve in South Africa has stoked concerns that organized poaching syndicates are targeting wildlife protectors.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: The Forgotten Virus: Zika Families and Researchers Struggle for Support
item.description: Some babies born with devastating birth defects from the mosquito-borne illness are 7 now, but Covid turned the world’s attention away.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Dado Galdieri
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Verônica Santos spends her days and nights never more than a few feet away from her son, João Guilherme, 7, who needs constant help with the most basic living functions.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The detention of Ukrainians by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed school bus in the rural Ukrainian village of Vilkhivka, outside the northeastern city of Kharkiv. The village was occupied by Russian forces in the spring.

item.title: Kenya Elects New President, but Disputes Erupt
item.description: Kenya is often held up as a beacon of democracy in Africa, but as the latest election showed, it is not always pretty. Disputes started even before a winner was named.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Abdi Latif Dahir and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Supporters of William Ruto celebrating his victory in one of his strongholds, Eldoret, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Will Not Release $3.5 Billion in Frozen Afghan Funds for Now, Citing Terror Fears
item.description: An American official said the United States could not guarantee that the money would not fall into terrorist hands, so it has ruled out releasing it anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighters celebrating the first anniversary of the group’s takeover of Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.

item.title: U.N. Chief and Russian Defense Minister Discuss Nuclear Power Plant Threat
item.description: The threat of a meltdown looms large after several days of shelling in the area.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex, across the Dnipro River from Nikopol, Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Forces in Kherson Pose Big Challenge for Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian forces badly want to retake the southern region of Kherson from Russian invaders, but Moscow retains a potentially overwhelming advantage.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position in the Mykolaiv region last week.

item.title: The Stabbing of Salman Rushdie Renews Free Speech Debates
item.description: After the attack, writers and world leaders hailed Rushdie as a symbol of free expression. But the battle lines around his novel “The Satanic Verses” were never cleanly drawn.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: Copies of Salman Rushdie’s “The Satanic Verses” being burned in Britain after it was published in 1988. Mr. Rushdie was stabbed last week in Western New York.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Kenya’s Next President?
item.description: Plus reports of Russian torture of Ukrainian prisoners and a longer sentence for Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Supporters of William Ruto, Kenya’s President elect, celebrated in Eldoret, Kenya, on Monday.

item.title: Scotland Makes Period Products Free
item.description: The country is the first to offer tampons, sanitary pads and other menstrual products free of charge.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: The Scottish Parliament passed the Period Products Act, which enshrines in law the free supply of sanitary products.

item.title: French Soldiers Quit Mali After 9 Years, Billions Spent and Many Lives Lost
item.description: The last unit of the French military mission, Operation Barkhane, crossed into neighboring Niger, after a major fallout with Malian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: French Foreign Legion troops in northeastern Mali in 2020.

item.title: Who Is William Ruto, Kenya’s New President Elect?
item.description: Mr. Ruto grew up poor, tending his family’s livestock in a remote village. As a presidential candidate, he appealed to the “hustler nation” of disenfranchised strivers, saying he was once like them.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: William Ruto after casting his ballot in Sugoi, Kenya, last week.

item.title: To Escape the War, Ukraine’s Factories Are Moving West
item.description: The government is working to save hundreds of businesses from Russian bombs, remaking western Ukraine into the country’s new economic heartland.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at Matro Luxe, one of Ukraine’s biggest mattress makers, which relocated to Ukraine’s western frontier.

item.title: Ukraine Claims It Hit Wagner Group Base in Popasna
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Cassandra Vinograd

item.title: Shelling near a Ukrainian nuclear plant has hit the fire station it uses for emergencies, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex, along the banks of the Dnipro River, is occupied by Russian forces, but still operated by Ukrainian technicians.

item.title: Germany’s €9 Monthly Train Pass Has Proved Popular (and a Pleasant Surprise)
item.description: To help offset inflation, Germany’s government has subsidized cheap train passes this summer. While many feared chaos and overcrowding on an overburdened system, it has been a relatively smooth ride.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The central train station in Hamburg, Germany. This summer, a government subsidy has let passengers buy all-you-can-ride monthly passes for 9 euros.

item.title: Ukraine makes gains in Kherson, but Russia’s advantage holds.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times

item.title: 18 Children Killed in Fire at Egyptian Coptic Orthodox Church
item.description: At least 41 people died from smoke inhalation and a stampede when a fire swept through a Coptic Orthodox church on Sunday. The church said a generator started the blaze.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: Huweida Hosni, her head bowed, is overcome by grief as the three children she lost in an explosion and fire at the Abu Sefein Church in Cairo are among those mourned during a funeral for some victims.

item.title: Oil Prices Fall After Signs of Chinese Economic Slowdown
item.description: A set of weak economic data and unexpected interest rate cuts in China led to a sharp sell-off, driven by concerns over sluggish demand in the world’s biggest oil importer.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: U.K. Approves Covid Booster Vaccine That Targets Two Variants
item.description: Britain is the first country to approve the Moderna-made vaccine, which generated a strong immune response against both the original virus and the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (Great Britain)
item.media:description: A clinician preparing doses of a Moderna vaccine at a vaccination center in London in December.

item.title: Six Weeks of ‘Hell’: Inside Russia’s Brutal Ukraine Detentions
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainian civilians have suffered beatings and sometimes electrical shocks, while the U.N. says hundreds have disappeared into Russian jails.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vasiliy, 37, who was beaten and subjected to electrical shocks under interrogation, is one of the few Ukrainians who have returned home after being detained in Russia.

item.title: Iran Denies Any Involvement in Stabbing of Salman Rushdie
item.description: But a spokesman for Iran’s Foreign Ministry, in the first remarks from the government since the assault, said the prizewinning author had crossed “red lines.”
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Salman Rushdie in 2015. He was the subject of a fatwa from Iran’s supreme leader in 1989, ordering Muslims to kill him over his novel “The Satanic Verses.”

item.title: You’re Being Watched
item.description: Employers have a new tool in the struggle with employees over workplace power: constant monitoring.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dora Potts, editor in chief of a test prep service, in her home office in Minnesota.

item.title: Myanmar Widens Arrests and Slaps Aung San Suu Kyi With More Prison Time
item.description: The ousted civilian leader has been convicted on corruption charges by a military-appointed court. A Japanese journalist and two models have also been detained in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2019, when she was state counselor of Myanmar. She was detained in a coup last year and has been in prison in Naypyidaw, the capital, since June.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Defense Team Appeals Drug Conviction in Russia
item.description: The appeal process could take months, but a senior Russian diplomat said that talks with the United States about a possible prisoner exchange were underway.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the American basketball star, leaving the courtroom in Khimki outside Moscow this month. She was found guilty of bringing illegal narcotics into the country.

item.title: China Pushes Its Vision for Taiwan As U.S. Delegation Visits
item.description: Beijing has seized on the tensions over Taiwan, further fanned by a meeting between five U.S. lawmakers and the island’s president, to push a far-reaching vision for unification.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Tourists on the Chinese island of Pingtan, facing the Taiwan Strait.

item.title: Reckoning With Memories of Budapest
item.description: A Times journalist spent three months capturing a contemporary portrait of Hungary’s capital, where he lived for several years as a child in the early ’90s.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The focus of fighting shifts to Ukraine’s south.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: As fighting raged around a nuclear plant, a Ukrainian family joined a convoy of civilians fleeing the area Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Fallout from the F.B.I.’s search of Donald Trump’s home.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A news conference held by Republican members of the House Intelligence Committee to discuss the F.B.I. raid.

item.title: India’s Partition: A History in Photos
item.description: The division set off communal violence and displaced millions, changing the face and geopolitics of South Asia.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Mikko Takkunen

item.title: 75 Years Later, the Fading Ghosts of India’s Bloody Partition
item.description: With the passing decades, nationalist fervor and mutual suspicion have largely replaced memories of mass death and displacement during the chaotic cleaving of Pakistan from India.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jagtar Kaur, who lives on the Indian side of the Punjab region, returned to her ancestral home in Pakistan in 2014.

item.title: Threat to Ukraine Nuclear Plant Increases as Fighting Rages
item.description: Russia, trying to pin down Ukraine’s forces to blunt a counteroffensive in Kherson, has been firing shells from near a nuclear plants it occupies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: As fighting raged around a nuclear plant, a Ukrainian family joined a convoy of civilians fleeing the area Sunday.
